texts.shortText:
As the name implies flatworms have wide, flat, leaf-like bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the body.  Many tropical species are very brightly-coloured, but those found in the temperate parts of South Africa tend to be more cryptic.

This species is flat and oval without a frilled margin or any dorsal projections. It is light brown in background colour and marked with a dense network of darker brown spots and patches. It is best identified by its obligate association with large limpets.
Typically about 10 mm body length, but can be up to 20 mm.

Global: The previous Notoplana patellarum was endemic to South Africa, but now that it and several other regional species have been amalgamated under the name Notocomplana erythrotaenia  it has become difficult to trace the wider global distribution.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to about East London.

Associated with large limpets, particularly the Goat’s-eye limpet Cymbula oculus. Live in the gill cavity between the foot of the limpet and the shell. There may be several flatworms associated with each individual limpet.

The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. This species is thought to feel on small crustaceans including commensal copepods that are also associated with the host limpets.

Flatworms are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilise one another by hypodermic impregnation – a process whereby the penis of one individual is stabbed into the partner and sperm injected into the body cavity. The spermatozoa then make their way to the ovaries of the receiving partner. Eggs are laid in gelatinous strings that are often deposited in spiral coils and hatch into free-swimming larvae. These float for a few days in the plankton before settling at new hosts.
Fairly easily recognized by its flat speckled-brown body and lack of dorsal tentacles, also by the fact that is found only under limpets.

Branch, G (1975). The ecology of Patella from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 5. Commensalism. Zoologica Africana, 10, 133-162.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 60)
